name: Cal_01
description: Distance between the most posteriorly projecting point on the tuberosity and the most anterior point on the superior margin of the articular facet for the cuboid measured in the sagittal plane and projected onto the underlying surface.
display_help: Distance between the most posteriorly projecting point on the tuberosity and the most anterior point on the superior margin of the articular facet for the cuboid measured in the sagittal plane and projected onto the underlying surface (Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #77; Holland 1995, MCAL; Langley et al. 2016:82, #94).
comment: Excessive calcaneal spurs should be omitted from this measurement.

name: Cal_02
description: Distance between the most laterally projecting point on the dorsal articular facet and the most medial point on the sustentaculum tali.
display_help: Distance between the most laterally projecting point on the dorsal articular facet and the most medial point on the sustentaculum tali (Martin and Knussmann 1988:225, #2; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #78; Langley et al. 2016:82, #95).
comment: The two measuring points lie at neither the same level, nor in a plane perpendicular to the sagittal plane. Span the calcaneus from behind with the blunt arms of the caliper so that the caliper is positioned in a flat and transverse plane across the bone.

name: Cal_03
display_name: Cal_03 Minimum Height Distal to Articular Facets
description: Find the minimum height in the pinched area of the calcaneus distal to the articular facets and proximal to the calcaneal tuber.
display_help: Find the minimum height in the pinched area of the calcaneus distal to the articular facets and proximal to the calcaneal tuber (Byrd and Adams 2015, #78A).

name: Cal_04
description: The maximum length between the most anterior point of the posterior talar articular surface and the most posterior point of the calcaneal tuberosity.
display_help: The maximum length between the most anterior point of the posterior talar articular surface and the most posterior point of the calcaneal tuberosity (Byrd and Adams 2015, #78B; Holland, 1995).

name: Cal_05
display_name: Cal_05 Maximum Length of the Calcaneus
description: Maximum length of the calcaneus as taken parallel to the long axis.  Hold the calcaneus in anatomical position so that you are looking down on the articular surface.  Place the fixed jaw of the digital calipers on the anterior-most point of the articular surface.  Extend the movable jaw to the posterior surface of bone in a line parallel to the long axis.
display_help: Maximum length of the calcaneus as taken parallel to the long axis.  Hold the calcaneus in anatomical position so that you are looking down on the articular surface.  Place the fixed jaw of the digital calipers on the anterior-most point of the articular surface.  Extend the movable jaw to the posterior surface of bone in a line parallel to the long axis.

name: Cap_01
display_name: Cap_01 Maximum Length of the Capitate
description: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers.
display_help: This is the maximum length of the bone. (Byrd and Adams 2015, #52.5L).
comment: Move the bone up, down, and sideways in order to obtain the maximum distance.

name: Cer1_01
display_name: Cer1_01 Maximum Length of the Left Superior Articular Facet
description: Take the maximum length of the facet as it appears in any direction.
display_help: Take the maximum length of the facet as it appears in any direction (Byrd and Adams 2015, #81A).

name: Cer1_02
display_name: Cer1_02 Maximum Length of the Right Superior Articular Facet
description: Take the maximum length of the facet as it appears in any direction.
display_help: Take the maximum length of the facet as it appears in any direction (Byrd and Adams 2015, #81A).

name: Cer1_03
display_name: Cer1_03 Maximum Length of the Left Inferior Articular Facet
description: Take the maximum length of the facet as it appears in any direction.
display_help: Take the maximum length of the facet as it appears in any direction (Byrd and Adams 2015, #81M).

name: Cer1_04
display_name: Cer1_04 Maximum Length of the Right Inferior Articular Facet
description: Take the maximum length of the facet as it appears in any direction.
display_help: Take the maximum length of the facet as it appears in any direction (Byrd and Adams 2015, #81M).

name: Cer2_01
display_name: Cer2_01 Maximum Length of the Left Superior Articular Facet
description: Take the maximum length of the facet as it appears in any direction (Byrd and Adams 2015, #81B).
display_help: Take the maximum length of the facet as it appears in any direction.

name: Cer2_02
display_name: Cer2_02 Maximum Length of the Right Superior Articular Facet
description: Take the maximum length of the facet as it appears in any direction (Byrd and Adams 2015, #81B).
display_help: Take the maximum length of the facet as it appears in any direction.

name: Cla_01
description: Maximum distance between the most extreme ends of the clavicle.
display_help: Maximum distance between the most extreme ends of the clavicle (Martin and Knussmann 1988:197, #1; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #35; Langley et al. 2016:73, #38).
comment: Place the bone on the osteometric board and place the sternal end of the clavicle against the vertical end board. Press the movable upright against the acromial end and move the bone up, down and sideways until the maximum length is obtained.

name: Cla_02
display_name: Cla_02 Maximum Diameter of the Clavicle at Midshaft
description: The maximum diameter of the bone measured at midshaft.
display_help: The maximum diameter of the bone measured at midshaft (Langley et al. 2016:73, #39).
comment: Determine the midpoint of the diaphysis on the osteometric board and mark it with a pencil. Place the bone between the two arms of the caliper and rotate the bone until the maximum diameter is obtained.

name: Cla_03
display_name: Cla_03 Minimum Diameter of the Clavicle at Midshaft
description: The minimum diameter of the bone measured at midshaft.
display_help: The minimum diameter of the bone measured at midshaft (Langley et al. 2016:74, #40).
comment: Determine the midpoint of the diaphysis on the osteometric board and mark it with a pencil. Place the bone between the two arms of the caliper and rotate the bone until the minimum diameter is obtained.

name: Cla_04
description: Distance from the anterior to the posterior surface at midshaft.
display_help: Distance from the anterior to the posterior surface at midshaft (Martin 1957:528, #5; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #36).
comment: Determine the midpoint of the diaphysis on the osteometric board and mark it with a pencil. Then determine sagittal diameter.

name: Cla_05
description: Distance from the superior to the inferior surface at midshaft (Martin 1957:528, #1; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #37).
display_help: Distance from the superior to the inferior surface at midshaft.
comment: Taken perpendicular to sagittal diameter.

name: Cla_06
display_name: Cla_06 Maximum Width at the Distal End
description: The maximum width of the distal end of the clavicle where the calipers are in contact with the rough attachment area, taken perpendicular to the shaft. Avoid angling the calipers (Byrd and Adams 2015, #37A).
display_help: The maximum width of the distal end of the clavicle where the calipers are in contact with the rough attachment area, taken perpendicular to the shaft. Avoid angling the calipers.

name: Cla_07
display_name: Cla_07 Breadth at the Inflexion Point at the Distal End
description: Anchor the caliper in the concave curve of the inflexion point at the distal end of the clavicle and place the other jaw of the caliper on the opposite side usually on or near the tubercle.
display_help: Anchor the caliper in the concave curve of the inflexion point at the distal end of the clavicle and place the other jaw of the caliper on the opposite side usually on or near the tubercle (Byrd and Adams 2015, #37B).

name: Cla_08
display_name: Cla_08 Maximum thickness at the Inflexion Point at the Distal End
description: The maximum thickness in the same vertical plane as the previous measurement (take perpendicular to 37B).
display_help: The maximum thickness in the same vertical plane as the previous measurement (take perpendicular to 37B) (Byrd and Adams 2015, #37C).

name: Cla_09
display_name: Cla_09 Maximum Anterior-Posterior Width at the Proximal End
description: The maximum anterior-posterior width of the proximal end (be sure to hold in anatomical position).
display_help: The maximum anterior-posterior width of the proximal end (be sure to hold in anatomical position) (Byrd and Adams 2015, #37D).

name: Cra_01
description: Distance between glabella (g) and opisthocranion (op) in the midsagittal plane, measured in a straight line .
display_help: Distance between glabella (g) and opisthocranion (op) in the midsagittal plane, measured in a straight line (Howells 1973: 170; Martin and Knussmann 1988:168 #1; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #1; Langley et al. 2016:65, #1).
comment: Set the skull on its base. Place one caliper point in the glabellar region in the midline and hold with fingers while the other caliper point is applied to the posterior portion of the skull in the midsagittal plane and moved up and down until the maximum length is obtained. On finding this, move the left point up and down slightly to make sure the reading is maximum.

name: Cra_02
description: Maximum length in the mid-sagittal plane, measured from nasion (n).
display_help: Maximum length in the mid-sagittal plane, measured from nasion (n) (Howells 1973:171; Langley et al. 2016:65, #2).
comment: With the skull in position as for glabello-occipital length (Maximum Cranial Length), place the one caliper point at nasion and move the other point along the occiput in the midline for the maximum reading.

name: Cra_03
description: Maximum width of skull perpendicular to midsagittal plane wherever it is located, with the exception of the inferior temporal lines and the area immediately surrounding them.
display_help: Maximum width of skull perpendicular to midsagittal plane wherever it is located, with the exception of the inferior temporal lines and the area immediately surrounding them (Howells 1973:172; Hrdlicka 1920:14; Martin and Knussmann 1988:170, #8; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #2; Langley et al. 2016:65, #3).
comment: Maximum Cranial Breadth is measured with the skull resting either on its base or on the occiput. The two measuring points (eurya) should lie in the same horizontal and frontal planes. Place the arms of the caliper at the same level while maintaining the hinge joint of the caliper in the mid-sagittal plane. Hold the ends of the caliper in each hand and apply to the lateral portions of the skull, making circular motions. Make sure you include areas below the squamosal suture, where the maximum is sometimes found.

name: Cra_04
description: Direct distance between most lateral points on the zygomatic arches.
display_help: Direct distance between most lateral points on the zygomatic arches (Howells 1973:173; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #3; Langley et al. 2016:66, #4).
comment: Place the skull on its occiput, base toward observer, and apply the blunt points of the caliper to the zygomatic arches and locate the maximum breadth perpendicular to the mid-sagittal plane.

name: Cra_05
description: Direct distance from the lowest point on the anterior margin of foramen magnum (ba), to bregma (b).
display_help: Direct distance from the lowest point on the anterior margin of foramen magnum (ba), to bregma (b)  (Howells 1973:172; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #4; Langley et al. 2016:66, #5).
comment: Place the skull on its occiput with the right side facing the observer. Apply the endpoint of one of the arms of the caliper at basion and support with fingers. Then apply the endpoint of the second arm of the caliper to bregma.

name: Cra_06
description: Direct distance from nasion (n) to basion (ba).
display_help: Direct distance from nasion (n) to basion (ba) (Howells 1973:171-172, Martin and Knussmann 1988:169, #5; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #5; Langley et al. 2016:66, #6).
comment: Rest the skull on the cranial vault and apply the endpoint of the one arm of caliper to nasion (n) while applying the other to basion (ba).

name: Cra_07
description: Direct distance from basion (ba) to prosthion (pr).
display_help: Direct distance from basion (ba) to prosthion (pr) (Howells 1973:174; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #6; Langley et al. 2016:66, #7).
comment: Apply the fixed point of the sliding caliper or one tip of the spreading caliper to prosthion (pr). Then bring the movable point of the sliding caliper or the other tip of the spreading caliper to basion (ba).

name: Cra_08
description: Maximum breadth across the alveolar borders of the maxilla measured on the lateral surfaces at the location of the second maxillary molars (ecm).
display_help: Maximum breadth across the alveolar borders of the maxilla measured on the lateral surfaces at the location of the second maxillary molars (ecm) (Howells 1973:176; Martin and Knussmann 1988:182 #61; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #7; Langley et al. 2016:66, #8).
comment: The points of measurement (ecm) are not found on the alveolar processes when reactive alveolar bone is present; in these cases ecm is located on the bony segment superior to the second maxillary molars. Apply both arms of the caliper to the alveolar borders above the tooth row from an anterior position.

name: Cra_09
description: Direct distance from prosthion (pr) to alveolon (alv).
display_help: Direct distance from prosthion (pr) to alveolon (alv) (Martin and Knussmann 1988:182 #60; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #8; Langley et al. 2016:66, #9).
comment: Place the skull so the base faces up. Apply a thin wire, rubber band, or other similar implement to the posterior borders of the alveolar arch and measure the distance from prosthion (pr) to the middle of the wire/band in the mid-sagittal plane (alv).

name: Cra_10
description: Least exterior breadth across the roots of the zygomatic processes (au), wherever found.
display_help: Least exterior breadth across the roots of the zygomatic processes (au), wherever found (Howells 1973:173; Martin and Knussmann 1988:170, #11b; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #9; Langley et al. 2016:66, #10).
comment: With the skull resting on the occiput and with the base toward the observer measure to the outside of the roots of the zygomatic processes at their deepest incurvature, generally slightly anterior to the external auditory meatus, with the sharp points of the caliper.

name: Cra_11
description: Direct distance from nasion (n) to prosthion (pr).
display_help: Direct distance from nasion (n) to prosthion (pr) (Howells 1973:174; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #10; Langley et al. 2016:66-67, #11).
comment: Place the fixed point of the caliper on nasion and apply the movable point to prosthion. If the alveolar process exhibits slight resorption or erosion at the point of prosthion, the projection of the process may be estimated when the alveolar process of the lateral incisors is still intact. When resorption or erosion is more pronounced this measurement should not be taken.

name: Cra_12
description: Direct distance between the two frontotemporale (ft).
display_help: Direct distance between the two frontotemporale (ft).
comment: Place the skull on its base. The two endpoints of the caliper are placed on the temporal ridges at the two frontotemporale (Hrdlicka 1920: 15; Martin and Knussmann 1988:170, #9; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #11; Langley et al. 2016:67, #12). When taking this measurement make certain that the least distance between both temporal lines on the frontal bone is recorded.

name: Cra_13
description: Direct distance between the two external points on the frontomalar suture (fmt).
display_help: Direct distance between the two external points on the frontomalar suture (fmt) (Martin and Knussmann 1988:179, #43; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #12; Langley et al. 2016:67, #13).
comment: The measurement is taken between the two external points on the frontomalar suture.

name: Cra_14
description: Direct distance from nasion (n) to the midpoint of a line connecting the lowest points of the inferior margin of the nasal notches (ns).
display_help: Direct distance from nasion (n) to the midpoint of a line connecting the lowest points of the inferior margin of the nasal notches (ns) (Howells 1973:175; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #13; Langley et al. 2016:67, #14).
comment: Place the skull on its occiput, base to the right, and measure the distance from nasion to the inferior border of the nasal aperture on each side and take the average of these two measurements to the nearest whole millimeter. The lower border of the aperture is well defined in most populations. It is not always the most anterior edge, but the beginning of the actual floor of the nasal cavity. It is the hinder border, not the forward border, of any prenasal gutter or fossa.

name: Cra_15
description: Maximum breadth of the nasal aperture (al-al).
display_help: Maximum breadth of the nasal aperture (al-al) (Howells 1973: 176; Martin and Knussmann 1988:181 #54; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #14; Langley et al. 2016:68, #15).
comment: Carefully place the points of the instrument on the sharp lateral margins of the nasal aperture at its most lateral curvature; this is not an inside measurement. The measurement is perpendicular to the mid-sagittal plane and recorded to the nearest millimeter.

name: Cra_16L
description: Laterally sloping distance from dacryon (d) to ectoconchion (ec).
display_help: Laterally sloping distance from dacryon (d) to ectoconchion (ec) (Howells 1973: 175; Martin and Knussmann l988:181, #51a; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #15; Langley et al. 2016:68, #16).
comment: The inside jaws of the calipers are useful for this measurement. For standardization and practical reasons measure the left orbit. Measure the right orbit if the left orbit is damaged and record the side measured on the recording sheet.

name: Cra_16R
description: Laterally sloping distance from dacryon (d) to ectoconchion (ec).
display_help: Laterally sloping distance from dacryon (d) to ectoconchion (ec) (Howells 1973: 175; Martin and Knussmann l988:181, #51a; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #15; Langley et al. 2016:68, #16).
comment: The inside jaws of the calipers are useful for this measurement. For standardization and practical reasons measure the left orbit. Measure the right orbit if the left orbit is damaged and record the side measured on the recording sheet.

name: Cra_17L
description: Direct distance between the superior and inferior margins taken perpendicular to the orbital breadth.
display_help: Direct distance between the superior and inferior margins taken perpendicular to the orbital breadth (Howells 1973: 175; Martin and Knussmann 1988:181, #52; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #16; Langley et al. 2016:68, #17).
comment: Orbital height is measured perpendicular to orbital breadth. Any notches or depressions on either superior or inferior borders should be avoided; if there is deep notching, move the caliper medially slightly. The inside jaws of the calipers are useful for this measurement.

name: Cra_17R
description: Direct distance between the superior and inferior margins taken perpendicular to the orbital breadth.
display_help: Direct distance between the superior and inferior margins taken perpendicular to the orbital breadth (Howells 1973: 175; Martin and Knussmann 1988:181, #52; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #16; Langley et al. 2016:68, #17).
comment: Orbital height is measured perpendicular to orbital breadth. Any notches or depressions on either superior or inferior borders should be avoided; if there is deep notching, move the caliper medially slightly. The inside jaws of the calipers are useful for this measurement.

name: Cra_18
description: Direct distance between right and left ectoconchion (ec).
display_help: Direct distance between right and left ectoconchion (ec) (Howells 1973:178; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #17; Langley et al. 2016:68, #18).

name: Cra_19
description: Direct distance between right and left dacryon (d).
display_help: Direct distance between right and left dacryon (d) (Howells 1973:178; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #18; Langley et al. 2016:69, #19).

name: Cra_20
description: Direct distance from nasion (n) to bregma (b) taken in the midsagittal plane.
display_help: Direct distance from nasion (n) to bregma (b) taken in the midsagittal plane (Howells 1973:181; Martin and Knussmann 1988:174, #29; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #19; Langley et al. 2016:69, #20).
comment: Place the tips of the instrument on the bone surface or at the level of the bone surface and not in a suture or other depression.

name: Cra_21
description: Direct distance from bregma (b) to lambda (l) taken in the midsagittal plane.
display_help: Direct distance from bregma (b) to lambda (l) taken in the midsagittal plane (Howells 1973:182; Martin and Knussmann 1988:175, #30; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #20; Langley et al. 2016:69, #21).
comment: Place the tips of the instrument on the bone surface or at the level of the bone surface and not in a suture or other depression.

name: Cra_22
description: Direct distance from lambda (l) to opsithion (o) taken in the midsagittal plane.
display_help: Direct distance from lambda (l) to opsithion (o) taken in the midsagittal plane (Howells 1973:182; Martin and Knussmann 1988:175, #31; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #21; Langley et al. 2016:69, #22).

name: Cra_23
description: Direct distance from basion (ba) to opisthion (o).
display_help: Direct distance from basion (ba) to opisthion (o) (Martin and Knussmann 1988:169 #7; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #22; Langley et al. 2016:69, #23).
comment: Measure with the skull base up, using the inside jaws of the calipers.

name: Cra_24
description: Distance between the lateral margins of foramen magnum at the points of greatest lateral curvature.
display_help: Distance between the lateral margins of foramen magnum at the points of greatest lateral curvature (Martin and Knussmann 1988:171, #16; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #23; Langley et al. 2016:69, #24).
comment: Measure with the skull base up using the inside jaws of the calipers.

name: Cra_25L
description: Vertical projection of the mastoid process below and perpendicular to the eye-car (Frankfort) plane.
display_help: Vertical projection of the mastoid process below and perpendicular to the eye-car (Frankfort) plane (Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #24; Langley et al. 2016:69-70, #25).
comment: Note that both right and left sides are measured. Place the fixed arm of the caliper on porion and move the movable arm until it touches mastoidale. This may be most easily accomplished by holding the calipers in a coronal plane. Howells (1973:176) and Martin and Knussmann (1988:172, #19a) define this measurement similarly, though their measurement technique differs from that described here. When only one value is needed, average the right and left measurements. If the discrepancy between the sides is more than 2mm repeat as a check.

name: Cra_25R
description: Vertical projection of the mastoid process below and perpendicular to the eye-car (Frankfort) plane.
display_help: Vertical projection of the mastoid process below and perpendicular to the eye-car (Frankfort) plane (Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #24; Langley et al. 2016:69-70, #25).
comment: Note that both right and left sides are measured. Place the fixed arm of the caliper on porion and move the movable arm until it touches mastoidale. This may be most easily accomplished by holding the calipers in a coronal plane. Howells (1973:176) and Martin and Knussmann (1988:172, #19a) define this measurement similarly, though their measurement technique differs from that described here. When only one value is needed, average the right and left measurements. If the discrepancy between the sides is more than 2mm repeat as a check.

name: Cra_26
description: Straight line distance from left to right asterion.
display_help: Straight line distance from left to right asterion (Howells 1973:174; Martin and Knussmann 1988:171, #12; Langley et al. 2016:70, #26).
comment: With the skull resting so that the occiput is facing the observer, measure the distance using the sharp points of the calipers.

name: Cra_27
description: The breadth across the maxillae, from the left to the right zygomaxillare anterior (zma).
display_help: The breadth across the maxillae, from the left to the right zygomaxillare anterior (zma) (Howells 1973:177; Langley et al. 2016:70, #27).
comment: The endpoints of the measurement are located on the facial surface and not on the inferior aspect of the zygomaxillary suture.

name: Cra_28
description: The distance between right and left zygoorbitale (zo).
display_help: The distance between right and left zygoorbitale (zo) (Langley et al. 2016:70, #28).

name: Cub_01
display_name: Cub_01 Maximum Length of the Cuboid
description: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers.
display_help: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers.(Byrd and Adams 2015, #80F)
comment: Move the bone up, down, and sideways in order to obtain the maximum distance, in the same manner that maximum length is obtained for the humerus, femur, etc.

name: Fem_01
description: Distance from the most superior point on the head of the femur to the most inferior point on the distal condyles.
display_help: Distance from the most superior point on the head of the femur to the most inferior point on the distal condyles (Hrdlicka 1920:128; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #60; Langley et al. 2016:78, #75).
comment: Place the femur parallel to the long axis of the osteometric board and resting on its posterior surface. Press the medial or lateral condyle against the vertical end board while applying the movable upright to the femoral head. Move the bone up, down, and sideways until the maximum length is obtained.

name: Fem_02
description: Distance from the most superior point on the head to a plane drawn along the inferior surfaces of the distal condyles.
display_help: Distance from the most superior point on the head to a plane drawn along the inferior surfaces of the distal condyles (Hrdlicka 1920:128; Martin and Knussmann 1988:216, #2; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #61; Langley et al. 2016:78, #76).
comment: Place the femur on the osteometric board so that the bone is resting on its posterior surface. Press both distal condyles against the vertical end board while applying the movable upright to the head of the femur.

name: Fem_03
description: Distance between the two most laterally projecting points on the epicondyles.
display_help: Distance between the two most laterally projecting points on the epicondyles (Martin and Knussmann 1988:218, #21; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #63; Langley et al. 2016:79, #77).
comment: Place the femur on the osteometric board so that it is resting on its posterior surface. Press one of the epicondyles against the vertical end board while applying the movable upright to the other condyle.

name: Fem_04
description: The maximum diameter of the femur head, wherever it occurs.
display_help: The maximum diameter of the femur head, wherever it occurs (Dwight 1905:21; Montagu 1960:70; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #63; Langley et al. 2016:79, #78).
comment: Rotate the arms of the caliper around the femur head to find the maximum diameter.

name: Fem_05
description: Distance between anterior and posterior surfaces at the proximal end of the diaphysis, measured perpendicular to the medial-lateral diameter.
display_help: Distance between anterior and posterior surfaces at the proximal end of the diaphysis, measured perpendicular to the medial-lateral diameter (Martin and Knussman 1988:217 #9; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #65; Langley et al. 2016:79-80, #79).
comment: The transverse diameter is oriented parallel to the anterior surface of the femur neck. Close attention should be paid to assessing this plane in femoral necks with a significant degree of torsion. In cases where this cannot be determined (e.g. where the lateral surfaces remain parallel) this measurement is recorded in the region 2-5 cm below the lesser trochanter.

name: Fem_06
description: Distance between the medial and lateral surfaces of the proximal end of the diaphysis at the point of its greatest lateral expansion below the base of the lesser trochanter.
display_help: Distance between the medial and lateral surfaces of the proximal end of the diaphysis at the point of its greatest lateral expansion below the base of the lesser trochanter (Martin and Knussman 1988:217, #10; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #64; Langley et al. 2016:80, #80).

name: Fem_07
description: Distance between anterior and posterior surfaces measured approximately at the midpoint of the diaphysis, at the highest elevation of linea aspera.
display_help: Distance between anterior and posterior surfaces measured approximately at the midpoint of the diaphysis, at the highest elevation of linea aspera (Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #66).
comment: The sagittal diameter should be measured perpendicular to the anterior bone surface.

name: Fem_08
description: Distance between the medial and lateral surfaces at midshaft, measured perpendicular to the anterior-posterior diameter.
display_help: Distance between the medial and lateral surfaces at midshaft, measured perpendicular to the anterior-posterior diameter (Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #67).

name: Fem_09
display_name: Fem_09 Maximum Midshaft Diameter of the Femur
description: The maximum diameter of the femoral shaft taken at midshaft.
display_help: The maximum diameter of the femoral shaft taken at midshaft (Langley et al. 2016:80, #81).
comment: Mark the midshaft of the bone with a pencil. Using sliding calipers to measure with one hand, rotate the bone with the other hand until the maximum diameter is obtained.

name: Fem_10
display_name: Fem_10 Minimum Midshaft Diameter of the Femur
description: The minimum diameter of the femoral shaft taken at midshaft.
display_help: The minimum diameter of the femoral shaft taken at midshaft (Langley et al. 2016:80, #82).
comment: Mark the midshaft of the bone with a pencil. Using sliding calipers to measure with one hand, rotate the bone with the other hand until the minimum diameter is obtained.

name: Fem_11
description: Circumference measured at the level of the midshaft diameters.
display_help: Circumference measured at the level of the midshaft diameters (Martin and Knussmann 1988:217, #8; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #68; Langley et al. 2016:80, #83).
comment: If the linea aspera is unusually hypertrophied at midshaft, this measurement should be recorded approximately 10 mm above the midshaft.

name: Fem_12
display_name: Fem_12 Maximum Anterio-posterior Length of the Lateral Condyle
description: The distance between the most anterior and posterior points on the articular surface of the lateral condyle.
display_help: The distance between the most anterior and posterior points on the articular surface of the lateral condyle (Langley et al. 2016:80, #84).
comment: Holding the femur with the distal end up, orient the measuring arms of the caliper with the long axis of the bone to obtain this measurement.

name: Fem_13
display_name: Fem_13 Maximum Anterio-posterior Length of the Medial Condyle
description: The distance between the most anterior and posterior points on the articular surface of the medial condyle.
display_help: The distance between the most anterior and posterior points on the articular surface of the medial condyle (Langley et al. 2016:80-81, #85).
comment: Holding the femur with the distal end up, orient the measuring arms of the caliper with the long axis of the bone to obtain this measurement.

name: Fem_14
display_name: Fem_14 Minimum Anterior-Posterior Diameter of the Diaphysis
description: The minimum anterior-posterior diameter anywhere along the diaphysis.  The linea aspera and condyles should be utilized in order to orient the bone in anatomical position (use the condyles to orient).
display_help: The minimum anterior-posterior diameter anywhere along the diaphysis.  The linea aspera and condyles should be utilized in order to orient the bone in anatomical position (use the condyles to orient) (Byrd and Adams 2003, #68A).

name: Fem_15
display_name: Fem_15 Minimum Medial-Lateral Diameter of the Diaphysis
description: The minimum medial-lateral diameter anywhere along the diaphysis.  The linea aspera and condyles should be utilized in order to orient the bone (should be taken in a perpendicular orientation to 68A) (Byrd and Adams 2003, #69B).
display_help: The minimum medial-lateral diameter anywhere along the diaphysis.  The linea aspera and condyles should be utilized in order to orient the bone (should be taken in a perpendicular orientation to 68A).

name: Fem_16
description: The minimum distance from the superior surface to the inferior surface on the femoral neck (Seidemann et al., 1998). Place caliper in the saddle of the neck (superior) and close inferior caliper arm, moving as necessary to find the minimum.
display_help: The minimum distance from the superior surface to the inferior surface on the femoral neck (Seidemann et al., 1998). Place caliper in the saddle of the neck (superior) and close inferior caliper arm, moving as necessary to find the minimum (Byrd and Adams 2003, #69D).

name: Fem_17
display_name: Fem_17 Maximum Diameter along the Linea Aspera
description: The maximum shaft diameter at any point along the linea aspera.  As the bone should be rotated to obtain the maximum distance, the measurement does not necessarily have to include the linea aspera, though it likely will.
display_help: The maximum shaft diameter at any point along the linea aspera.  As the bone should be rotated to obtain the maximum distance, the measurement does not necessarily have to include the linea aspera, though it likely will (Byrd and Adams 2003, #69E).

name: Fem_18
description: The distance from the apex of the head of the femur to the lateral side of the femur diaphysis, measured in line with the neck of the femur such that the line of measurement bisects the neck.  Using sliding calipers, place the fixed jaw on the most prominent point on the femur head.  Place the movable jaw on the lateral margin of the femur diaphysis so that the line formed between the two points splits the neck into two equal portions .
display_help: The distance from the apex of the head of the femur to the lateral side of the femur diaphysis, measured in line with the neck of the femur such that the line of measurement bisects the neck.  Using sliding calipers, place the fixed jaw on the most prominent point on the femur head.  Place the movable jaw on the lateral margin of the femur diaphysis so that the line formed between the two points splits the neck into two equal portions (Simmons et al. 1990).

name: Fem_19
description: On the lateral condyle of the distal femur, it is the distance from the most superior point on the condyle to the most inferior point.  Holding the femur in anatomical position with the distal condyles facing the observer, place the fixed jaw of the sliding caliper on the top of the condyle and place the movable jaw on the most inferior point on the condyle.  The femur should be held so that it is possible to accurately judge the location of the most inferior point.
display_help: On the lateral condyle of the distal femur, it is the distance from the most superior point on the condyle to the most inferior point.  Holding the femur in anatomical position with the distal condyles facing the observer, place the fixed jaw of the sliding caliper on the top of the condyle and place the movable jaw on the most inferior point on the condyle.  The femur should be held so that it is possible to accurately judge the location of the most inferior point (Simmons et al. 1990).

name: Fib_01
description: Maximum distance between the most superior point on the fibula head and the most inferior point on the lateral malleolus.
display_help: Maximum distance between the most superior point on the fibula head and the most inferior point on the lateral malleolus (Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #75; Langley et al. 2016:82, #92).
comment: Place the fibula on the osteometric board and place the tip of the lateral malleolus against the vertical end board. Press the movable upright against the proximal end of the bone while moving it up and down and sideways to obtain the maximum length.

name: Fib_02
description: Maximum diameter at the midshaft.
display_help: Maximum diameter at the midshaft (Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #76; Langley et al. 2016:82, #93).
comment: Find the midpoint on the osteometric board and mark with a pencil. Place the diaphysis of the fibula between the two arms of the caliper while turning the bone to obtain the maximum diameter.

name: Fib_03
display_name: Fib_03 Maximum Diameter of the Diaphysis
description: This measurement should only be taken along the interosseous crest (avoid measurements of the shaft near the epiphyses).
display_help: This measurement should only be taken along the interosseous crest (avoid measurements of the shaft near the epiphyses) (Byrd and Adams 2015, #76A).

name: Fib_04
display_name: Fib_04 Minimum Diameter of the Diaphysis
description: The minimum distance at any point along the diaphysis.
display_help: The minimum distance at any point along the diaphysis (Byrd and Adams 2015, #76B).

name: Fib_05
display_name: Fib_05 Maximum Breadth at the Distal End
description: Place one jaw of the caliper on the posterior portion (tubercle) and extend the other jaw to the opposite side (just above the malleolar articular surface) to find the maximum distance.
display_help: Place one jaw of the caliper on the posterior portion (tubercle) and extend the other jaw to the opposite side (just above the malleolar articular surface) to find the maximum distance (Byrd and Adams 2015, #76C).

name: Cf1_01
display_name: Cf1_01 Maximum Length of the 1st Cuneiform
description: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers.
display_help: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers (Byrd and Adams 2015, #80H).
comment: Move the bone up, down, and sideways in order to obtain the maximum distance, in the same manner that maximum length is obtained for the humerus, femur, etc.

name: Ham_01
display_name: Ham_01 Maximum Length of the Hamate
description: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers.
display_help: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers (Byrd and Adams 2015, #52.5M).
comment: Move the bone up, down, and sideways in order to obtain the maximum distance.

name: Hum_01
description: Direct distance from the most superior point on the head of the humerus to the most inferior point of the trochlea.
display_help: Direct distance from the most superior point on the head of the humerus to the most inferior point of the trochlea (Hrdlicka 1920:126; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #40; Langley et al. 2016:74, #45).
comment: Place the humerus on the osteometric board so that its long axis parallels theinstrument. Place the head of the humerus against the vertical end board and press the movable upright against the trochlea. Move the bone up, down and sideways to determine the maximum distance.

name: Hum_02
description: Distance of the most laterally protruding point on the lateral epicondyle from the corresponding project of the medial epicondyle.
display_help: Distance of the most laterally protruding point on the lateral epicondyle from the corresponding project of the medial epicondyle  (Martin and Knussmann 1988:199, #4; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #41; Langley et al. 2016:74, #46).

name: Hum_03
description: Direct distance between the most superior and inferior points on the border of the articular surface.
display_help: Direct distance between the most superior and inferior points on the border of the articular surface (Martin and Knussmann 1988:200, #10; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #42; Langley et al. 2016:74, #47).
comment: Do not include arthritic lipping which may be present on the perimeter of the joint surface. This diameter is not necessarily the maximum head diameter.

name: Hum_04
description: Maximum diameter at midshaft (Martin and Knussmann 1988:199, #5; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #43; Langley et al. 2016:74-75, #48).
display_help: Maximum diameter at midshaft.
comment: Determine the midpoint of the diaphysis on the osteometric board and mark with a pencil. Using sliding calipers to measure with one hand, rotate the bone with the other hand until the maximum diameter is obtained.

name: Hum_05
description: Minimum diameter of midshaft.
display_help: Minimum diameter of midshaft (Martin and Knussmann 1988:199, #6; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #44; Langley et al. 2016:75, #49).
comment: Determine the midpoint of the diaphysis on the osteometric board and mark with a pencil. Using sliding calipers to measure with one hand, rotate the bone with the other hand until the minimum diameter is obtained.

name: Hum_06
display_name: Hum_06 Total Breadth of the Capitulum-Trochlea
description: The breadth of the capitulum and trochlea at the distal humerus.  One end of the sliding calipers is positioned parallel to the flat, spool-shaped surface of the trochlea (medial), and the other end is moved until it comes into contact with the capitulum (lateral).
display_help: The breadth of the capitulum and trochlea at the distal humerus.  One end of the sliding calipers is positioned parallel to the flat, spool-shaped surface of the trochlea (medial), and the other end is moved until it comes into contact with the capitulum (lateral) (Byrd and Adams 2003, #41A).

name: Hum_07
display_name: Hum_07 Anterior-Posterior Breadth of the Head
description: The maximum breadth of the humeral head taken in the anterior-posterior direction on the articular surface.  This measurement is taken perpendicular from the vertical diameter of the humeral head (42).
display_help: The maximum breadth of the humeral head taken in the anterior-posterior direction on the articular surface.  This measurement is taken perpendicular from the vertical diameter of the humeral head (42) (Byrd and Adams 2003, #42A).

name: Hum_08
display_name: Hum_08 Minimum Diameter of the Diaphysis
description: The minimum diameter of the humeral diaphysis taken in any direction perpendicular to the shaft.  This measurement should be taken on the oval part of the shaft, superior to the flattening observed around the olecranon fossa and the lateral supracondylar ridge.  Often it is found near midshaft.
display_help: The minimum diameter of the humeral diaphysis taken in any direction perpendicular to the shaft.  This measurement should be taken on the oval part of the shaft, superior to the flattening observed around the olecranon fossa and the lateral supracondylar ridge.  Often it is found near midshaft (Byrd and Adams 2003, #44B).

name: Hum_09
display_name: Hum_09 Maximum Diameter of Diaphysis at the Deltoid Tuberosity
description: The maximum diameter of the diaphysis within the length of the deltoid tuberosity. Rotate and slide the element to find the maximum diameter.
display_help: The maximum diameter of the diaphysis within the length of the deltoid tuberosity. Rotate and slide the element to find the maximum diameter (Byrd and Adams 2003, #44D).

name: Lun_01
display_name: Lun_01 Maximum Length of the Lunate
description: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers.
display_help: This is the maximum length of the bone. The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers (Byrd and Adams 2015, #52.5G).
comment: Move the bone up, down, and sideways in order to obtain the maximum distance.

name: Man_01
description: Direct distance from infradentale (id) to gnathion (gn).
display_help: Direct distance from infradentale (id) to gnathion (gn) (Martin and Knussmann 1988:183, #69; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #25; Langley et al. 2016:71, #29).
comment: When the mandibular alveolar process is damaged between the central incisors, estimates of this measurement are recorded by using the intact alveolar process at the position of the lateral incisors. Any estimate or adjustment should be indicated on the recording form. In mandibles where the alveolar process exhibit pronounced erosion or resorption, this measurement is not taken.

name: Man_02L
display_name: Man_02L Height of the Left Mandibular Body
description: Direct distance from the alveolar process to the inferior border of the mandible perpendicular to the base at the level of the mental foramen.
display_help: Direct distance from the alveolar process to the inferior border of the mandible perpendicular to the base at the level of the mental foramen (Martin and Knussmann 1988:183, #69.1; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #26; Langley et al. 2016:71, #30).

name: Man_02R
display_name: Man_02R Height of the Right Mandibular Body
description: Direct distance from the alveolar process to the inferior border of the mandible perpendicular to the base at the level of the mental foramen.
display_help: Direct distance from the alveolar process to the inferior border of the mandible perpendicular to the base at the level of the mental foramen (Martin and Knussmann 1988:183, #69.1; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #26; Langley et al. 2016:71, #30).

name: Man_03L
display_name: Man_03L Breadth of the Left Mandibular Body
description: Maximum breadth measured in the region of the mental foramen perpendicular to the long axis of the mandibular body.
display_help: Maximum breadth measured in the region of the mental foramen perpendicular to the long axis of the mandibular body (Martin and Knussmann 1988:183, #69.3; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #27; Langley et al. 2016:71, #31).

name: Man_03R
display_name: Man_03R Breadth of the Right Mandibular Body
description: Maximum breadth measured in the region of the mental foramen perpendicular to the long axis of the mandibular body.
display_help: Maximum breadth measured in the region of the mental foramen perpendicular to the long axis of the mandibular body (Martin and Knussmann 1988:183, #69.3; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #27; Langley et al. 2016:71, #31).

name: Man_04
description: Direct distance between right and left gonion (go)  (Martin and Knussmann 1988:182, #66; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #28; Langley et al. 2016:71, #32).
display_help: Direct distance between right and left gonion (go).
comment: Apply the blunt points of the caliper arms to the most prominent external points at the mandibular angles.

name: Man_05
description: Direct distance between the most lateral points of the two condyles (cdl) .
display_help: Direct distance between the most lateral points of the two condyles (cdl)  (Martin and Knussmann 1988:182, #65; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #29; Langley et al. 2016:71, #33).
comment: Place the blunt point of the fixed end of the instrument against the right condyle and apply the movable end to the left condyle.

name: Man_06L
description: Least breadth of the mandibular ramus measured perpendicular to the height of the ramus.
display_help: Least breadth of the mandibular ramus measured perpendicular to the height of the ramus (Martin and Knussmann 1988:183, #71a; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #30; Langley et al. 2016:72, #34).
comment: The measurement is taken at the waist of the ramus (the point where the distance between the anterior and posterior margins of the ramus is the smallest).

name: Man_06R
description: Least breadth of the mandibular ramus measured perpendicular to the height of the ramus.
display_help: Least breadth of the mandibular ramus measured perpendicular to the height of the ramus (Martin and Knussmann 1988:183, #71a; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #30; Langley et al. 2016:72, #34).
comment: The measurement is taken at the waist of the ramus (the point where the distance between the anterior and posterior margins of the ramus is the smallest).

name: Man_07L
description: Distance between the most anterior point on the mandibular ramus and a line connecting the most posterior point on the condyle and the angle of the jaw.
display_help: Distance between the most anterior point on the mandibular ramus and a line connecting the most posterior point on the condyle and the angle of the jaw (Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #31).

name: Man_07R
description: Distance between the most anterior point on the mandibular ramus and a line connecting the most posterior point on the condyle and the angle of the jaw.
display_help: Distance between the most anterior point on the mandibular ramus and a line connecting the most posterior point on the condyle and the angle of the jaw (Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #31).

name: Man_08
description: Direct distance from the highest point on the mandibular condyle to gonion (go).
display_help: Direct distance from the highest point on the mandibular condyle to gonion (go) (Martin and Knussmann 1988:183, #70; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #32; Langley et al. 2016:72, #35).
comment: Apply movable board of the mandibulometer to the posterior borders of the mandibular rami and the fixed board against the most anterior point of the chin.

name: Man_09
description: Distance of the anterior margin of the chin from a center point on the projected straight line placed along the posterior border of the two mandibular angles.
display_help: Distance of the anterior margin of the chin from a center point on the projected straight line placed along the posterior border of the two mandibular angle (Martin and Knussmann 1988:185, #79; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #34; Langley et al. 2016:72, #37).
comment: In case of “rocker jaws”, the bone is held in place by pressing down on the second molars.

name: Man_10
description: Angle formed by the inferior border of the corpus and the posterior border of the ramus.
display_help: Angle formed by the inferior border of the corpus and the posterior border of the ramus (Martin and Knussmann 1988:185, #79; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #34; Langley et al. 2016:72, #37).
comment: In case of rocker jaw, the bone is held in place by pressing down on the second molars.

display_name: MC1_01 Maximum Length of the 1st Metacarpal
description: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers.
display_help: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers. (Byrd and Adams 2015, #52.5A)
