name: Osc_01
description: Distance from the most superior point on the iliac crest to the most inferior point on the ischial tuberosity.
display_help: Distance from the most superior point on the iliac crest to the most inferior point on the ischial tuberosity (Hrdlicka 1920:135; Martin and Knussmann 1988:213, #1; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #56; Langley et al. 2016:77, #64).
comment: When using an osteometric board, place the ischium against the vertical end board and press the movable upright against the iliac crest. Move the ilium sideways and up and down to obtain the maximum distance.

name: Osc_02
description: Distance from the anterior-superior iliac spine to the posterior-superior iliac spine.
display_help: Distance from the anterior-superior iliac spine to the posterior-superior iliac spine  (Martin and Knussmann 1988:213, #2; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #57; Langley et al. 2016:77, #65).

name: Osc_03
description: Distance from the point in the acetabulum where the three elements of the os coxa meet to the upper end of the pubic symphysis.
display_help: Distance from the point in the acetabulum where the three elements of the os coxa meet to the upper end of the pubic symphysis (Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #58).
comment: The measuring point in the acetabulum may be identified in the adult by (1) an irregularity which is frequently visible, both on the acetabular and pelvic surfaces; (2) a change in thickness which may be seen by holding the bone up to a light; (3) a notch often present in the border of the articular surface in the acetabulum. In measuring the pubis, care should be taken to hold the caliper parallel to the long axis of the bone.

name: Osc_04
description: Distance from the point in the acetabulum where the three elements meet to the deepest point on the ischial tuberosity.
display_help: Distance from the point in the acetabulum where the three elements meet to the deepest point on the ischial tuberosity (Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #59).
comment: Ischium length should be measured approximately perpendicular to pubis length.

name: Osc_05
description: Position one end of the calipers in the sciatic notch and place the opposing jaw in the concavity either above or below the anterior inferior iliac spine (AIIS) to find the minimum distance. The measurement will usually be taken inferior to the AIIS. Once the jaws of the calipers are in a concavity bordering the AIIS, move the opposing jaws within the sciatic notch to find the minimum distance.
display_help: Position one end of the calipers in the sciatic notch and place the opposing jaw in the concavity either above or below the anterior inferior iliac spine (AIIS) to find the minimum distance. The measurement will usually be taken inferior to the AIIS. Once the jaws of the calipers are in a concavity bordering the AIIS, move the opposing jaws within the sciatic notch to find the minimum distance (Langley et al. 2016:77, #66; Byrd and Adams 2015, #59D).

name: Osc_06
description: The distance between symphysion (the most superior point on the symphyseal face to the farthest point on the acetabular rim.
display_help: The distance between symphysion (the most superior point on the symphyseal face to the farthest point on the acetabular rim (Langley et al. 2016:77, #67).
comment: The measurement is taken to the rim itself (not inside or outside the rim).

name: Osc_07
description: The distance between symphysion (the most superior point on the symphyseal face) to the closest point on the acetabular rim.
display_help: The distance between symphysion (the most superior point on the symphyseal face) to the closest point on the acetabular rim (Langley et al. 2016:77, #68).
comment: The measurement is taken to the rim itself (not inside or outside the rim).

name: Osc_08
description: The distance from the point on the acetabular rim where the iliac blade meets the acetabulum to the most medial point on the epiphysis of the ischial tuberosity.
display_help: The distance from the point on the acetabular rim where the iliac blade meets the acetabulum to the most medial point on the epiphysis of the ischial tuberosity (Langley et al. 2016:77, #69).
comment: If the borders of the epiphysis cannot be determined, do not take this measurement.

name: Osc_09
description: The distance from the most medial point on the epiphysis of the ischial tuberosity to the closest point on the acetabular rim.
display_help: The distance from the most medial point on the epiphysis of the ischial tuberosity to the closest point on the acetabular rim (Langley et al. 2016:78, #70).
comment: If the borders of the epiphysis cannot be determined, do not take this measurement.

name: Osc_10
description: The distance from the most inferior point on the symphyseal face to the most distance point on the ischial tuberosity.
display_help: The distance from the most inferior point on the symphyseal face to the most distance point on the ischial tuberosity (Langley et al. 2016:78, #71).

name: Osc_11
display_name: Osc_11 Anterior Superior Iliac Spine to Symphysion (ASISS)
description: Measurement from the apex of the anterior superior iliac spine (most projecting area or point) to symphysion.
display_help: Measurement from the apex of the anterior superior iliac spine (most projecting area or point) to symphysion (Langley et al. 2016:78, #72).

name: Osc_12
display_name: Osc_12 Maximum Posterior Iliac Spine to Symphysion (PSISS)
description: Maximum measurement from the posterior border of the posterior superior iliac spine to symphysion.
display_help: Maximum measurement from the posterior border of the posterior superior iliac spine to symphysion (Langley et al. 2016:78, #73).

name: Osc_13
display_name: Osc_13 Minimum Apical Border to Symphysion (WAS)
description: Minimum measurement from the symphysion to the apex (anterior border) of the auricular surface.
display_help: Minimum measurement from the symphysion to the apex (anterior border) of the auricular surface (Langley et al. 2016:78, #74).

name: Osc_14
display_name: Osc_14 Thickness of the Ilium at the Sciatic Notch
description: Position one end of the calipers along the arcuate line, adjacent to the apex of the auricular surface.  Slide the opposing end of the calipers to the posterior surface of the ilium to obtain the measurement.
display_help: Position one end of the calipers along the arcuate line, adjacent to the apex of the auricular surface.  Slide the opposing end of the calipers to the posterior surface of the ilium to obtain the measurement (Byrd and Adams 2008, #59A).

name: Osc_15
display_name: Osc_15 Maximum Breadth of the Ischium
description: Position one end of the calipers in the obturator foramen and place the other end on the ischial tuberosity. Move the calipers around to find the maximum distance.
display_help: Position one end of the calipers in the obturator foramen and place the other end on the ischial tuberosity. Move the calipers around to find the maximum distance  (Byrd and Adams 2015, #59B).

name: Osc_16
display_name: Osc_16 Minimum Breadth of the Pubis
description: Position the calipers along the iliopubic ramus; rotate and slide the calipers to find the minimum distance. Use the pointed edges of the calipers instead of the flat so as not to obstruct the measurement.
display_help: Position the calipers along the iliopubic ramus; rotate and slide the calipers to find the minimum distance. Use the pointed edges of the calipers instead of the flat so as not to obstruct the measurement  (Byrd and Adams 2015, #59C).

name: Osc_17
display_name: Osc_17 Maximum Diameter of the Acetabulum
description: The maximum distance of the acetabulum taken at any two points along the articular border of the lunate surface (look at the acetabulum from the side and take the measurement at the peaks of the ridges).  This distance is commonly found in line with the iliac crest and the ischial tuberosity.
display_help: The maximum distance of the acetabulum taken at any two points along the articular border of the lunate surface (look at the acetabulum from the side and take the measurement at the peaks of the ridges).  This distance is commonly found in line with the iliac crest and the ischial tuberosity (Byrd and Adams 2008, #59E).

name: Pat_01
description: Find the maximum length of the patella.
display_help: Find the maximum length of the patella (Byrd and Adams 2015, #74.5A).

name: Pat_02
description: Find the maximum breadth of the patella.
display_help: Find the maximum breadth of the patella (Byrd and Adams 2015, #74.5B).

name: Pat_03
description: Find the maximum thickness of the patella.
display_help: Find the maximum thickness of the patella (Byrd and Adams 2015, #74.5C).

name: Pis_01
display_name: Pis_01 Maximum Length of the Pisiform
description: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers.
display_help: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers (Byrd and Adams 2015, #52.5I).
comment: Move the bone up, down, and sideways in order to obtain the maximum distance.

name: Rad_01
description: Distance from the most proximally positioned point on the head of radius to the tip of the styloid process without regard for the long axis of the bone.
display_help: Distance from the most proximally positioned point on the head of radius to the tip of the styloid process without regard for the long axis of the bone (Martin and Knussmann 1988:201, #1; Hrdlicka 1920:127; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #45; Langley et al. 2016:75, #50).
comment: Place the proximal end against the vertical upright of the osteometric board and press the movable upright against the distal end. Move the bone up, down and sideways to obtain the maximum length.

name: Rad_02
display_name: Rad_02 Maximum Diameter of the Radius at Midshaft
description: The maximum diameter of the radial shaft taken at midshaft.
display_help: The maximum diameter of the radial shaft taken at midshaft (Langley et al. 2016:75, #51).
comment: Mark the midshaft of the bone with a pencil. Using sliding calipers to measure with one hand, rotate the bone with the other hand until the minimum diameter is obtained.

name: Rad_03
display_name: Rad_03 Minimum Diameter of the Radius at Midshaft
description: The minimum diameter of the radial shaft taken at midshaft.
display_help: The minimum diameter of the radial shaft taken at midshaft (Langley et al. 2016:75, #52).
comment: Mark the midshaft of the bone with a pencil. Using sliding calipers to measure with one hand, rotate the bone with the other hand until the minimum diameter is obtained.

name: Rad_04
display_name: Rad_04 Maximum Diameter of the Head
description: Position the calipers around the radial head and rotate the bone until the maximum distance is obtained.
display_help: Position the calipers around the radial head and rotate the bone until the maximum distance is obtained (Montagu 1960:68; Langley et al. 2016:75, #53; Byrd and Adams 2003, #47D).

name: Rad_05
description: Distance between anterior and posterior surfaces at midshaft.
display_help: Distance between anterior and posterior surfaces at midshaft (Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #46).
comment: Determine the midpoint of the diaphysis on the osteometric board and mark with a pencil. Measure sagittal diameter at that point. This measurement is almost always less than the medial-lateral diameter.

name: Rad_06
description: Distance between medial and lateral surfaces at midshaft.
display_help: Distance between medial and lateral surfaces at midshaft (Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #47).
comment: Perpendicular to anterior-posterior diameter.

name: Rad_07
display_name: Rad_07 Maximum Diameter at the Radial Tuberosity
description: The maximum shaft diameter on the radial tuberosity.  Position the calipers around the tuberosity and rotate the bone until the maximum distance is obtained.
display_help: The maximum shaft diameter on the radial tuberosity.  Position the calipers around the tuberosity and rotate the bone until the maximum distance is obtained (Byrd and Adams 2003, #47A).

name: Rad_08
display_name: Rad_08 Maximum Diameter of the Diaphysis Distal to the Radial Tuberosity
description: The maximum shaft diameter distal to the radial tuberosity, positioned along the interosseous crest.  The bone should be rotated to find the maximum distance.
display_help: The maximum shaft diameter distal to the radial tuberosity, positioned along the interosseous crest.  The bone should be rotated to find the maximum distance (Byrd and Adams 2003, #47B).

name: Rad_09
display_name: Rad_09 Minimum Diameter of the Diaphysis Distal to the Radial Tuberosity
description: The minimum shaft diameter anywhere distal to the radial tuberosity.  The bone may be rotated to find the minimum distance.
display_help: The minimum shaft diameter anywhere distal to the radial tuberosity.  The bone may be rotated to find the minimum distance (Byrd and Adams 2003, #47C).

name: Rad_10
display_name: Rad_10 Breadth of the Distal Epiphysis
description: The maximum distance from the ulnar notch to the lateral aspect of the styloid process.  The medial protrusions (articular borders of the ulnar notch) are placed against the vertical endboard of the osteometric board (sliding calipers may also be used) and the movable portion is applied to the lateral surface of the styloid process to find the maximum breadth (Byrd and Adams 2003, #47E).
display_help: The maximum distance from the ulnar notch to the lateral aspect of the styloid process.  The medial protrusions (articular borders of the ulnar notch) are placed against the vertical endboard of the osteometric board (sliding calipers may also be used) and the movable portion is applied to the lateral surface of the styloid process to find the maximum breadth.

name: Sac_01
display_name: Sac_01 Anterior Height of the Sacrum
description: Distance from a point on the promontory positioned in the midsagittal plane to a point on the anterior border of the tip of the sacrum measured in the midsagittal plane.
display_help: Distance from a point on the promontory positioned in the midsagittal plane to a point on the anterior border of the tip of the sacrum measured in the midsagittal plane (Martin and Knussmann 1988:195, #2; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #53; Langley et al. 2016:76, #60).
comment: Place the pointed tips of the caliper on the promontory and the anterior inferior border of the fifth sacral vertebra. The measurement is taken in the mid- sagittal plane. If a sacrum exhibits more than five segments, measure to the bottom segment and indicate the number of segments on the recording form. If the coccyx is fused to the sacrum do not include in the measurement.

name: Sac_02
display_name: Sac_02 Anterior Breadth of the Sacrum
description: Maximum transverse breadth of the sacrum at the level of the anterior projection of the auricular surface.
display_help: Maximum transverse breadth of the sacrum at the level of the anterior projection of the auricular surface (Martin and Knussmann 1988:195, #5; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #54; Langley et al. 2016:76, #61).

name: Sac_03
display_name: Sac_03 Transverse Diameter of Sacral Segment 1
description: The distance between the two most lateral points on the superior articular surface measured perpendicular to the midsagittal plane.
display_help: The distance between the two most lateral points on the superior articular surface measured perpendicular to the midsagittal plane (Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #55; Langley et al. 2016:77, #62).
comment: The measurement should be taken on the superior articular surface of S1. When lipping of the articular surface is present approximate the original articular borders. This measurement is perpendicular to the AP Diameter of S1.

name: Sac_04
display_name: Sac_04 Anterior-Posterior Diameter of Sacral Segment 1
description: The distance between the anterior and posterior borders of the superior articular surface of sacral segment 1, taken in the mid-sagittal plane.
display_help: The distance between the anterior and posterior borders of the superior articular surface of sacral segment 1, taken in the mid-sagittal plane (Langley et al. 2016:77, #63).
comment: The measurement should be taken on the superior articular surface of S1. When lipping of the articular surface is present approximate the original articular borders. This measurement is perpendicular to the Transverse Diameter of S1.

name: Sac_05
display_name: Sac_05 Maximum Breadth with the Osteometric Board
description: Position the sacrum on the osteometric board and find the maximum breadth of the alae.
display_help: Position the sacrum on the osteometric board and find the maximum breadth of the alae (Byrd and Adams 2015, #55J).

name: Scp_01
display_name: Scp_01 Maximum Length of the Scaphoid
description: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers.
display_help: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers (Byrd and Adams 2015, #52.5F).
comment: Move the bone up, down, and sideways in order to obtain the maximum distance.

name: Sca_01
description: Direct distance from the most superior point of the cranial angle to the most inferior point on the caudal angle.
display_help: Direct distance from the most superior point of the cranial angle to the most inferior point on the caudal angle (Martin and Knussmann 1988:197, #1; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #38; Langley et al. 2016:74, #41).

name: Sca_02
description: Distance from the midpoint on the dorsal border of the glenoid fossa to midway between the two ridges of the scapular spine on the vertebral border.
display_help: Distance from the midpoint on the dorsal border of the glenoid fossa to midway between the two ridges of the scapular spine on the vertebral border.
comment: Project a line through the obtuse angle of a triangle formed by the vertebral border and the two ridges of the spine, dividing it into two equal halves. The medial measuring point is located where this line intersects the vertebral border (Hrdlicka 1920:131; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #39; Langley et al. 2016:74, #42).

name: Sca_03
description: The maximum length (superior/inferior) of the glenoid fossa.  The measurement is taken on the articular margin of the fossa.  Often a distinct rim is visible (look at the fossa from the side and take the measurement at the apex of the ridges). The maximum length is generally superior-inferior.
display_help: The maximum length (superior/inferior) of the glenoid fossa.  The measurement is taken on the articular margin of the fossa.  Often a distinct rim is visible (look at the fossa from the side and take the measurement at the apex of the ridges). The maximum length is generally superior-inferior (Martin and Knussmann 1988:198, #12; Langley et al. 2016:74, #44; Byrd and Adams 2015, #39A).
comment: Place one flat surface of the jaw of the calipers on the anterior side of the glenoid fossa and place the flat surface of the other jaw on the posterior side with both jaws oriented parallel to the long axis of the bone.

name: Sca_04
description: The maximum breadth (anterior/posterior) of the glenoid fossa.  Place one flat surface of the jaw of the calipers on the anterior side of the glenoid fossa and place the flat surface of the other jaw on the posterior side with both jaws oriented parallel to the long axis of the bone. The measurement is taken roughly perpendicular to the length (39A). If lipping interferes with measurement, don’t take measurement on lipped surface, but estimate on surface of fossa.
display_help: The maximum breadth (anterior/posterior) of the glenoid fossa.  Place one flat surface of the jaw of the calipers on the anterior side of the glenoid fossa and place the flat surface of the other jaw on the posterior side with both jaws oriented parallel to the long axis of the bone. The measurement is taken roughly perpendicular to the length (39A). If lipping interferes with measurement, don’t take measurement on lipped surface, but estimate on surface of fossa (Byrd and Adams 2015, #39B).

name: Sca_05
display_name: Sca_05 Minimum Length from Scapular Notch to Axillary Border
description: This measurement is the minimum distance from the superior border (typically in the notch) to the axillary border. Anchor a jaw of the caliper in the notch and use the other jaw to find the minimum distance to a point on the axillary border.
display_help: This measurement is the minimum distance from the superior border (typically in the notch) to the axillary border. Anchor a jaw of the caliper in the notch and use the other jaw to find the minimum distance to a point on the axillary border (Byrd and Adams 2015, #39D).

name: Cf2_01
display_name: Cf2_01 Maximum Length of the 2nd Cuneiform
description: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers.
display_help: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers (Byrd and Adams 2015, #80I).
comment: Move the bone up, down, and sideways in order to obtain the maximum distance, in the same manner that maximum length is obtained for the humerus, femur, etc.

name: Tal_01
description: This is the minimum breadth of the trochlea (superior articular surface).  Place the flat surfaces of the jaws of the sliding calipers on either side of the articular surface with the jaws (approximately) parallel to the long axis of the bones. Close the jaws to take the minimum value.
display_help: This is the minimum breadth of the trochlea (superior articular surface).  Place the flat surfaces of the jaws of the sliding calipers on either side of the articular surface with the jaws (approximately) parallel to the long axis of the bones. Close the jaws to take the minimum value (Byrd and Adams 2008, #79).

name: Tal_02
description: The maximum length between the most anterior point of the head and the posterior tubercle (Holland, 1995).
display_help: The maximum length between the most anterior point of the head and the posterior surface of the tibial articulation. Position the fixed caliper arm along the posterior surface of the tibial articulation and bring the calipers closed on the most anterior point of the head (Holland, 1995; Byrd and Adams 2015, #79A).

name: Tal_03
description: The maximum length between the most anterior point of the head and the posterior surface of the tibial articulation. Position the fixed caliper arm along the posterior surface of the tibial articulation and bring the calipers closed on the most anterior point of the head.
display_help: The maximum length between the most anterior point of the head and the posterior tubercle (Holland, 1995; Byrd and Adams 2015, #79B).

name: Cf3_01
display_name: Cf3_01 Maximum Length of the 3rd Cuneiform
description: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers.
display_help: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers (Byrd and Adams 2015, #80J).
comment: Move the bone up, down, and sideways in order to obtain the maximum distance, in the same manner that maximum length is obtained for the humerus, femur, etc.

name: Tib_01
description: Distance from the superior articular surface of the lateral condyle to the tip of the medial malleolus.
display_help: Distance from the superior articular surface of the lateral condyle to the tip of the medial malleolus (Hrdlicka 1920:129; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #69; Langley et al. 2016:81, #86).
comment: An osteometric board with a hole for the intercondylar eminence makes this measurement easier to take. Place the tibia on the osteometric board resting on its posterior surface with the longitudinal axis of the bone parallel to the board (Hrdlicka 1920:129). If using an osteometric board without a hole, place the tibia on the osteometric board so that it the long axis is parallel to the board. The measurement is taken from the lateral condyle to the tip of the medial malleolus.

name: Tib_02
description: Maximum distance between the two most laterally projecting points on the medial and lateral condyles of the proximal articular region.
display_help: Maximum distance between the two most laterally projecting points on the medial and lateral condyles of the proximal articular region (Martin and Knussmann 1988:221, #3; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #70; Langley et al. 2016:81, #87).
comment: Place the tibia on the osteometric board resting on its posterior surface. Press the lateral condyle against the vertical end board, and place the movable upright against the medial condyle. Tibiae exhibiting marked torsion may have to be rotated to obtain the maximum breadth.

name: Tib_03
description: Maximum distance between the two most laterally projecting points on the medial malleolus and the lateral surface of the distal articular region (epiphysis).
display_help: Maximum distance between the two most laterally projecting points on the medial malleolus and the lateral surface of the distal articular region (epiphysis)  (Martin and Knussmann 1988:221, #6; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #71; Langley et al. 2016:81, #88).
comment: Place the two lateral protrusions of the distal epiphysis against the fixed side of the osteometric board and move the sliding board until it contacts the medial malleolus.

name: Tib_04
display_name: Tib_04 Maximum Diameter at the Nutrient Foramen
description: Distance between the anterior crest and the posterior surface at the level of the nutrient foramen.
display_help: Distance between the anterior crest and the posterior surface at the level of the nutrient foramen (Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #72).

name: Tib_05
display_name: Tib_05 Medial-Lateral (Transverse) Diameter at the Nutrient Foramen
description: Straight line distance of the medial margin from the interosseous crest at the level of the nutrient foramen.
display_help: Straight line distance of the medial margin from the interosseous crest at the level of the nutrient foramen (Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #73).
comment: This is taken perpendicular to Maximum Diameter at the Nutrient Foramen.

name: Tib_06
display_name: Tib_06 Circumference at the Nutrient Foramen
description: Circumference measured at the level of the nutrient foramen.
display_help: Circumference measured at the level of the nutrient foramen (Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #74).

name: Tib_07
display_name: Tib_07 Maximum Midshaft Diameter of the Tibia
description: The maximum diameter of the tibial shaft taken at midshaft.
display_help: The maximum diameter of the tibial shaft taken at midshaft (Langley et al. 2016:81, #89).
comment: Mark the midshaft of the bone with a pencil. Using sliding calipers to measure with one hand, rotate the bone with the other hand until the maximum diameter is obtained.

name: Tib_08
display_name: Tib_08 Minimum Midshaft Diameter of the Tibia
description: The minimum diamter of the tibial shaft taken at midshaft.
display_help: The minimum diamter of the tibial shaft taken at midshaft (Martin and Knussmann 1988:573, #9a; Langley et al. 2016:81, #90).
comment: Mark the midshaft of the bone with a pencil. Using sliding calipers to measure with one hand, rotate the bone with the other hand until the minimum diameter is obtained.

name: Tib_09
display_name: Tib_09 Circumference of the Tibia at the Midshaft
description: The circumference measured at the level of the midshaft.
display_help: The circumference measured at the level of the midshaft (Martin and Knussmann 1988:574, #10a; Langley et al. 2016:82, #91).

name: Tib_10
display_name: Tib_10 Maximum Anterior-Posterior Diameter Distal to the Popliteal Line
description: This measurement should be taken at the most distal point of the popliteal line where it intersects with the margin of the diaphysis.  The calipers are rotated to find the maximum distance (this is the maximum diameter of the diaphysis at this point).  Note that the correct location may be difficult to determine in very gracile individuals.
display_help: This measurement should be taken at the most distal point of the popliteal line where it intersects with the margin of the diaphysis.  The calipers are rotated to find the maximum distance (this is the maximum diameter of the diaphysis at this point).  Note that the correct location may be difficult to determine in very gracile individuals (Byrd and Adams 2003, #74B).

name: Tib_11
description: Locate the minimum anterior-posterior distance at any point on the tibial shaft. Use the medial malleolus and anterior crest to orient the bone, particularly when torsion is present.
display_help: Locate the minimum anterior-posterior distance at any point on the tibial shaft. Use the medial malleolus and anterior crest to orient the bone, particularly when torsion is present (Byrd and Adams 2003, #74B).

name: Tib_12
display_name: Tib_12 Maximum Anterior-Posterior Distance of the Distal Articular Surface
description: Locate the maximum anterior-posterior distance of the distal articular surface by viewing the element from the side to find the peaks of the articular surface and measuring the distance between them. Use the medial malleolus to orient the bone.
display_help: Locate the maximum anterior-posterior distance of the distal articular surface by viewing the element from the side to find the peaks of the articular surface and measuring the distance between them. Use the medial malleolus to orient the bone (Byrd and Adams 2003, #74F).

name: Tib_13
description: Maximum breadth of the proximal articular surface of the tibia as measured from the lateral edge of the lateral condyle to the medial edge of the medial condyle.  This is not the maximum breadth of the proximal tibia, but rather the maximum breadth of the articular surface.  Holding the tibia so that the proximal articular surface is in plain view, place the fixed jaw of the digital caliper on the most lateral edge of the lateral condyle.  Extend the movable jaw to what appears to be the most medial edge of the medial condyle.  Pivot the movable jaw slightly to ensure that the maximum measure is found.
display_help: Maximum breadth of the proximal articular surface of the tibia as measured from the lateral edge of the lateral condyle to the medial edge of the medial condyle.  This is not the maximum breadth of the proximal tibia, but rather the maximum breadth of the articular surface.  Holding the tibia so that the proximal articular surface is in plain view, place the fixed jaw of the digital caliper on the most lateral edge of the lateral condyle.  Extend the movable jaw to what appears to be the most medial edge of the medial condyle.  Pivot the movable jaw slightly to ensure that the maximum measure is found (Holland 1992).

name: Tib_14
description: Maximum transverse width of the medial condyle as measured from lateral to medial edges.  The surface of the condyle generally is circumscribed by a slight rim, and points of the caliper should be placed on this rim.  Hold the tibia so that you can look directly down on the proximal articular surface.  Place the fixed jaw of the digital caliper on the medial edge of the condyle.  Extend the movable jaw to the lateral edge of the medial condyle.  Move the caliper anteriorly and then posteriorly, adjusting the jaws so that they always contact the opposing edges of the condyle. Find the maximum in this manner.
display_help: Maximum transverse width of the medial condyle as measured from lateral to medial edges.  The surface of the condyle generally is circumscribed by a slight rim, and points of the caliper should be placed on this rim.  Hold the tibia so that you can look directly down on the proximal articular surface.  Place the fixed jaw of the digital caliper on the medial edge of the condyle.  Extend the movable jaw to the lateral edge of the medial condyle.  Move the caliper anteriorly and then posteriorly, adjusting the jaws so that they always contact the opposing edges of the condyle. Find the maximum in this manner (Holland 1992).

name: Tib_15
description: Similar but perpendicular to width.  Measurement should record maximum length from the anterior edge of the medial condyle to the posterior margin.  Hold the tibia so that you can look directly down on the proximal articular surface.  Place the fixed jaw of the digital caliper on the anterior edge of the medial condyle.  Extend the movable jaw to the posterior edge of the condyle.  Move the caliper medially and then laterally, adjusting the jaws so that they always contact the opposing edges of the condyle. Find the maximum in this manner.
display_help: Similar but perpendicular to width.  Measurement should record maximum length from the anterior edge of the medial condyle to the posterior margin.  Hold the tibia so that you can look directly down on the proximal articular surface.  Place the fixed jaw of the digital caliper on the anterior edge of the medial condyle.  Extend the movable jaw to the posterior edge of the condyle.  Move the caliper medially and then laterally, adjusting the jaws so that they always contact the opposing edges of the condyle. Find the maximum in this manner (Holland 1992).

name: Tib_16
description: Maximum length of the lateral condyle as measured in a manner similar to that for MCL.
display_help: Maximum length of the lateral condyle as measured in a manner similar to that for MCL (Holland 1992).

name: Tzm_01
display_name: Tzm_01 Maximum Length of the Trapezium
description: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers.
display_help: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers (Byrd and Adams 2015, #52.5J).
comment: Move the bone up, down, and sideways in order to obtain the maximum distance.

name: Tzd_01
display_name: Tzd_01 Maximum Length of the Trapezoid
description: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers.
display_help: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers (Byrd and Adams 2015, #52.5K).
comment: Move the bone up, down, and sideways in order to obtain the maximum distance.

name: Tri_01
display_name: Tri_01 Maximum Length of the Triquetral
description: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers.
display_help: This is the maximum length of the bone.  The measurement should be taken with sliding calipers (Byrd and Adams 2015, #52.5H).
comment: Move the bone up, down, and sideways in order to obtain the maximum distance.

name: Uln_01
description: Distance from the most superior point on the olecranon to the most inferior point on the styloid process.
display_help: Distance from the most superior point on the olecranon to the most inferior point on the styloid process (Hrdlicka 1920:127; Martin and Knussmann 1988:204, #1; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #48; Langley et al. 2016:75-76, #54).
comment: Place the proximal end of the ulna against the vertical end board. Press the movable upright against the distal end while moving the bone up, down and sideways to obtain the maximum length.

name: Uln_02
display_name: Uln_02 Maximum Midshaft Diameter of the Ulna
description: The maximum diameter of the diaphysis at midshaft.
display_help: The maximum diameter of the diaphysis at midshaft (Langley et al. 2016:76, #55).
comment: Mark the midshaft of the bone with a pencil. Using sliding calipers to measure with one hand, rotate the bone with the other hand until the maximum diameter is obtained.

name: Uln_03
display_name: Uln_03 Minimum Midshaft Diameter of the Ulna
description: The minimum diameter of the diaphysis at midshaft
display_help: The minimum diameter of the diaphysis at midshaft (Langley et al. 2016:76, #56).
comment: Mark the midshaft of the bone with a pencil. Using sliding calipers to measure with one hand, rotate the bone with the other hand until the minimum diameter is obtained.

name: Uln_04
description: Maximum diameter of the diaphysis where the crest exhibits the greatest development in anterior-posterior (dorso-volar) plane.
display_help: Maximum diameter of the diaphysis where the crest exhibits the greatest development in anterior-posterior (dorso-volar) plane (Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #49).

name: Uln_05
description: Distance between medial and lateral surfaces at the level of greatest crest development.
display_help: Distance between medial and lateral surfaces at the level of greatest crest development (Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #50).
comment: Taken perpendicular to anterior-posterior diameter.

name: Uln_06
description: Distance between the most distal (inferior) point on the surface of the coronoid process and the most distal point on the inferior surface of the distal head of the ulna.
display_help: Distance between the most distal (inferior) point on the surface of the coronoid process and the most distal point on the inferior surface of the distal head of the ulna  (Martin and Knussmann 1988:204, #2; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #51).
comment: Do not include the styloid process or the groove between the styloid process and the distal articular surface.

name: Uln_07
description: Least circumference near the distal end of the bone.
display_help: Least circumference near the distal end of the bone  (Martin and Knussmann 1988:204, #3; Moore-Jansen et al. 1994, #52; Langley et al. 2016:76, #58).

name: Uln_08
description: The maximum breadth of the olecranon process, taken perpendicular to the longitudinal axis of the semilunar notch.
display_help: The maximum breadth of the olecranon process, taken perpendicular to the longitudinal axis of the semilunar notch  (Martin and Knussmann 1988:206, #6; Langley et al. 2016:76, #59).

name: Uln_09
display_name: Uln_09 Minimum Diameter of the Diaphysis Including Interosseous Crest
description: Locate the minimum diameter of the diaphysis along the portion of the bone that includes the interosseous crest.  This measurement may not necessarily include the interosseous crest, but should be taken on that part of the shaft that exhibits the crest.  This measurement is not always near the distal end of the crest.

name: Uln_10
display_name: Uln_10 Mimimum Diameter of the Diaphysis
description: This measurement will be found near the distal epiphysis of the ulna.  The bone should be rotated in order to locate the minimum distance.
display_help: This measurement will be found near the distal epiphysis of the ulna.  The bone should be rotated in order to locate the minimum distance (Byrd and Adams 2003, #51B).

name: Uln_11
display_name: Uln_11 Breadth of the Semilunar Notch
description: This is a measure of only the distal surface of the semilunar notch (the base).  In order to obtain the distance, one end of the calipers is positioned within the radial notch (approximate midpoint), roughly parallel to the shaft.  The other end of the calipers is applied to the medial edge of the semilunar notch to obtain the maximum distance. Calipers can be angled.
